reference: Volume Four, Issue Forty-Four, File 16 of 27
title: An Interview With Agent Steal
historical_context: This interview provides insight into the hacker culture of the early 1990s, particularly focusing on the collaboration between hackers and law enforcement, specifically the FBI.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article features an interview with Agent Steal, a former hacker turned FBI informant, discussing his experiences, motivations, and the dynamics of the hacker community during the early 90s.
summary:
In this revealing interview, Agent Steal shares his journey from being a hacker to becoming an informant for the FBI. He candidly discusses the pressures that led him to cooperate with law enforcement, including the potential for severe prison time due to possession of classified materials. Throughout the conversation, he reflects on his past associations with notorious hackers like Kevin Poulson and Ronald Austin, shedding light on the intricate relationships within the hacker community and the consequences of betrayal. Agent Steal's perspective offers a unique glimpse into the moral dilemmas faced by hackers when confronted with legal repercussions and the choice to cooperate with authorities.

The interview also delves into Agent Steal's hacking exploits, including phone tapping and manipulating telecommunications systems, which he describes with a mix of nostalgia and caution. He emphasizes the evolution of hacking techniques and the necessity for hackers to adapt to changing technologies. Agent Steal's experiences highlight the blurred lines between criminality and survival in the hacker world, as well as the ongoing cat-and-mouse game between hackers and law enforcement. His story serves as a cautionary tale for those in the hacking community, illustrating the risks and rewards of a life on the edge of legality.
